content: The "Hedge Fund Transparency Act" requires hedge funds to register. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine paragraphs and provide exemptions for issuers with a limited number of beneficial owners. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine paragraphs and provide exemptions for issuers with a limited number of beneficial owners, where beneficial ownership by a company is deemed to be beneficial ownership by one person, except in certain cases. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine paragraphs and provide exemptions for issuers with a limited number of beneficial owners. Beneficial ownership by a company is deemed to be ownership by one person in certain cases, such as legal separation, divorce, death, or other involuntary events. Issuers exclusively owned by qualified purchasers are subject to specific regulations. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine paragraphs and provide exemptions for issuers with a limited number of beneficial owners. Securities owned by qualified purchasers through gifts, bequests, or involuntary events are considered owned by qualified purchasers. Issuers with not more than 100 non-qualified purchaser owners are exempt under certain conditions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to provide exemptions for issuers with a limited number of beneficial owners. Qualified purchasers who acquired securities before September 1, 1996, and issuers with less than 100 non-qualified purchaser owners are eligible for exemptions under certain conditions. Issuers must disclose to beneficial owners that future investors will be limited to qualified purchasers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to provide exemptions for issuers with a limited number of beneficial owners. Issuers must disclose to beneficial owners the opportunity to redeem their interests in the issuer for a proportionate share of the net assets. Redeeming persons will receive cash or assets based on their share of the issuer's net assets. An issuer exempt under the Investment Company Act of 1940 must disclose the opportunity for beneficial owners to redeem their interests for a share of the issuer's assets. The issuer is still considered an investment company and must comply with certain limitations regarding the purchase and sale of securities issued by registered investment companies. Compliance with exemptions and regulations is necessary for such issuers. The issuer exempt under the Investment Company Act of 1940 is not treated as a single issuer for determining ownership limits. A limitation on exemptions for large investment companies is added. Compliance with exemptions and regulations is required for such issuers. Limitation on exemptions for large investment companies with assets over $50,000,000 requires registration, filing of information form, maintaining records, and cooperation with the Commission. The information form must be filed electronically and regularly. Large investment companies with assets over $50,000,000 must file information forms annually. The forms should include details on beneficial owners, ownership structure, affiliations, and key service providers. Large investment companies with assets over $50,000,000 are required to annually file information forms that include details on affiliations with financial institutions, minimum investment commitments, total number of investors, and current asset values. The information must be provided to the public in an electronic, searchable format at no cost. SEC. 3. IMPLEMENTING GUIDANCE AND RULES. The Securities and Exchange Commission must issue necessary forms and guidance within 180 days of this Act. They may also create rules to implement the Act. SEC. 4. ANTI-MONEY LAUNDERING OBLIGATIONS. The purpose of this section is to prevent financing of terrorist organizations and money laundering. Investment companies relying on specific sections of the Investment Company Act must establish an anti-money laundering program and report suspicious transactions. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with other agencies, will establish necessary policies, procedures, and controls for this purpose. Investment companies receiving exemptions under specific sections of the Investment Company Act must implement risk-based due diligence policies to identify and assess foreign persons supplying funds. Investment companies must implement risk-based due diligence policies to identify and assess foreign persons supplying funds, incorporating elements of the proposed rule for unregistered investment companies related to anti-money laundering programs. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to propose and issue the rule within specific timeframes after the enactment of this Act. The final rule must be implemented within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Subsection (b) will be effective one year after the Act's enactment, regardless of the final rule issuance under subsection (c). Failure to issue the rule will not impact the enforceability of this section. SEC. 5. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to update various sections. Securities Act of 1933 is amended in paragraphs 2, 4, and 13, while Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended in section 3(a)(12)(A). The Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to update various sections, including changes to section 3(c)(2), 3(c)(8)(B), 3(c)(12), and 6(a)(7). The Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to update various sections, including changes to section 3(c)(2), 3(c)(8)(B), 3(c)(12), and 6(a)(7) of the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to update section 6(a)(7) by replacing references to "excepted investment company" with "exempt investment company" and making other related changes. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to update section 6(a)(7) by replacing references to "excepted investment company" with "exempt investment company" and making related changes, such as inserting "any exempt" and updating references to exclusions from the definition of an investment company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to update various sections by replacing references to specific subsections with new ones, such as changing "section 3(c)(10)" to "section 3(c)(8)" and "section 3(c)(14)" to "section 3(c)(12)" in different provisions. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is also amended to align with these changes. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to update various sections by replacing references to specific subsections with new ones, such as changing "section 3(c)(14)" to "section 3(c)(12)" and "section 3(c)(11)" to "section 3(c)(9)" in different provisions. Additionally, the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by replacing "section 3(c)(3)" with "section 3(c)(2)" in the definition of regulated investment company.
